description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
help: Select element must have an accessible name
html: [['<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Form element has explicit <label> that is hidden']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://calendar.google.com/
        Error: select-name
        Description: Ensures select element has an accessible name
        Suggested change: Select element missing descriptive label.
        Incorrect: <select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required="" field="">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The error mentions that the select element doesn't have an accessible name. This usually means that there is no descriptive label associated with the select element. Since this is a Google Calendar website, it's likely that the 'CountryCode' field doesn't require an accessible name description because the options within the select dropdown are self-explanatory and the purpose of this field might be to select a country from a predefined list rather than needing a descriptive label for accessibility. However, to adhere to best practices, we should always ensure that elements have clear and user-friendly labels or names, especially when they are used for critical functions. Here's a possible fixed version:

Corrected: 
```
<select id="CountryCode" name="CountryCode" required>
    <option value="">Select a country</option>
    <option value="US">United States</option>
    <option value="CA">Canada</option>
    <!-- More options can be added here -->
</select>
```

In this version, I've added a default option that describes the purpose of the field, which could serve as an accessible name. This mimics a common approach for select fields where there might not be a traditional label due to space constraints or when the purpose of the field is clear from the options themselves.

failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable', 'Fix any of the following:\n  The landmark must have a unique aria-label, aria-labelledby, or title to make landmarks distinguishable']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://slack.com/
        Error: landmark-unique
        Description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
        Suggested change: Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels.
        Incorrect: <header role="banner">
<footer class="c-nav c-nav--footer">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The current code includes a `<header>` tag with `role="banner"`, but it does not have a unique accessible name. The footer also lacks a clear identity within the code, making it hard to identify its purpose without proper role or accessible name. To correct these issues, we can provide distinct roles and accessible names for the header and footer. Here's the suggested change:

Corrected code:

```html
<header role="banner" aria-label="Site header">
<footer role="contentinfo" aria-label="Site footer">
```

Explanation:
- The `<header>` tag now has a `role="banner"` and an `aria-label="Site header"` attribute. The `aria-label` attribute provides a clear, descriptive name for the header, which helps screen readers identify it as the site's header.
- The `<footer>` tag has a `role="contentinfo"` attribute to indicate that it contains information about the content of the document, and it also has an `aria-label="Site footer"` attribute to provide a clear, descriptive name for the footer.

These changes ensure that both the header and footer have unique roles and accessible names, improving the website's accessibility for users with disabilities.

description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
help: Zooming and scaling must not be disabled
html: [['<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  user-scalable=no on <meta> tag disables zooming on mobile devices']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://soundcloud.com/
        Error: meta-viewport
        Description: Ensures <meta name="viewport"> does not disable text scaling and zooming
        Suggested change: Meta viewport tag is missing or not configured correctly for responsive design.
        Incorrect: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width,minimum-scale=1,maximum-scale=1,user-scalable=no">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The provided `<meta name="viewport">` tag is already correctly configured for responsive design. It sets the viewport to the device width, allowing for minimum and maximum scaling of 1, and prevents user-scaling. However, it might not be in the most optimal position in the HTML file, as it should be placed in the `<head>` section of the HTML file. It's also good practice to include `initial-scale=1` for better control over the initial zoom level.

Correct: 
```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1, minimum-scale=1, maximum-scale=1, user-scalable=no">
    <!-- Other head content... -->
</head>
<body>
    <!-- Website content... -->
</body>
</html>
```
This ensures that the website is responsive and text can be scaled appropriately on different devices.

description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
help: Required ARIA attributes must be provided
html: [['<input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Required ARIA attribute not present: aria-expanded']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.audible.com/
        Error: aria-required-attr
        Description: Ensures elements with ARIA roles have all required ARIA attributes
        Suggested change: ARIA role missing required attribute.
        Incorrect: <input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" role="combobox">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The input element has an ARIA role attribute, but it is missing the required ARIA attributes such as `aria-labelledby` and `aria-expanded`. These attributes are necessary for correctly describing the input element's role and state to assistive technologies.

Corrected: 
```html
<input type="search" autocomplete="off" class="bc-input bc-color-border-focus bc-color-base bc-color-background-base bc-color-border-base" value="" data-initial-value="" id="header-search" placeholder="Find your next great listen" name="keywords" aria-label="Search for an audiobook, newspaper, magazine and more" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-controls="ac-listbox" aria-labelledby="search-label" aria-expanded="false" role="combobox">
```
Explanation:
- `aria-labelledby="search-label"` adds an ARIA attribute to link the input element with a label element (assuming there's a label element for this input) to improve accessibility.
- `aria-expanded="false"` is added to indicate that the input element is not currently expanded or open. This attribute is often used in conjunction with the `aria-haspopup` attribute, which is not explicitly mentioned in this example but should be considered if the input element has an associated popup or listbox.

By adding these attributes, the input element's role and state are more accurately described to assistive technologies such as screen readers, enhancing accessibility for users with disabilities.

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The given error and suggestion are referring to the ARIA (Accessible Rich Internet Applications) landmark roles that are used to guide screen readers and other assistive technologies in organizing the structure of web content. The 'main' landmark role is crucial as it helps to identify the primary content area of the web page. The suggested change is correct because a web page should only have one main content area, which is essential for accessibility. To fix this, the HTML structure should be revised to ensure that the main content area is clearly identified with the 'main' landmark role.

<html>
<head>

</head>
<body>
    <main role="main">
        <!-- content goes here -->
    </main>
</body>
</html>
```

In this corrected version, I've added a `<main>` element with the `role="main"` attribute. This ensures that only one 'main' landmark role is present on the page, which is in line with the suggested change, and it also helps in providing a clear structure for assistive technologies.

        Description: Ensures the document has at most one banner landmark
        Suggested change: Multiple elements are assigned the 'banner' landmark role, which should be unique.
        Incorrect: <header class="global-header js-globalheader desktop" data-interaction="mouse">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The issue is about the presence of multiple elements with the 'banner' landmark role, which should be unique in the document. This can lead to confusion for screen reader users who navigate through the document, as they might not be able to distinguish between the different banners.

Corrected: We'll ensure that only one element in the document has the 'banner' landmark role. For the header, it doesn't need to have the 'banner' role since it's not acting as a banner, but rather as a navigation header. Instead, we'll add semantic roles like 'masthead' or 'navigation' more appropriately.

Correct: 
```html
<header class="global-header js-globalheader desktop">
  <!-- Header content here -->
</header>
```

help: Frames must have an accessible name

failureSummary:
[['Fix any of the following:
  Element has no title attribute
  aria-label attribute does not exist or is empty
  aria-labelledby attribute does not exist, references elements that do not exist or references elements that are empty
  Element's default semantics were not overridden with role="none" or role="presentation"']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.bbc.com/
        Error: frame-title
        Description: Ensures <iframe> and <frame> elements have an accessible name
        Suggested change: Frame missing or has non-descriptive title attribute.
        Incorrect: <iframe name="edr_l_first" id="edr_l_first" frameborder="0" src="https://edigitalsurvey.com/l.php?id=INS-vt29-666188954&v=7291&x=1280&y=720&d=24&c=null&ck=1&p=%2F&fu=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2F&xdm=edr&xdm_o=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com&xdm_c=edr0" scrolling="no">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The provided code snippet is an `<iframe>` tag which has a `name`, `id`, `frameborder`, `src`, `scrolling` attributes. However, it lacks a descriptive title attribute. Title attributes in `<iframe>` tags are crucial as they provide a short description of the content that will be loaded within the frame, which is particularly important for screen readers and other assistive technologies. Without a title attribute, users with disabilities might not understand what content is being presented within the frame.

Corrected: 

```
<iframe name="edr_l_first" id="edr_l_first" frameborder="0" src="https://edigitalsurvey.com/l.php?id=INS-vt29-666188954&v=7291&x=1280&y=720&d=24&c=null&ck=1&p=%2F&fu=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com%2F&xdm=edr&xdm_o=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bbc.com&xdm_c=edr0" title="Embedded Digital Survey">
```

Explanation: 
- The `title` attribute has been added to the `<iframe>` tag with a descriptive text "Embedded Digital Survey". This text will be read by screen readers when the user navigates to this `<iframe>` element, providing context about the content that will be loaded within the frame.

        Description: Ensures role attribute has an appropriate value for the element

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The issue highlighted is about the `role` attribute which is incorrectly set to `listbox`. The element in question is a `select` tag, which should use the `role="select"` attribute instead to be in line with ARIA guidelines. This is important for accessibility as it correctly identifies the element for screen readers and other assistive technologies.

Correct: `<select aria-labelledby="global-footer-select-label" class="eds-field-styled__input eds-field-styled__select" role="select" id="global-footer-select" name="global-footer-select">`

description: Ensures every id attribute value used in ARIA and in labels is unique
help: IDs used in ARIA and labels must be unique
html: [['<input type="search" name="q" id="q" title="Search all IEEE websites" placeholder="Search all IEEE websites" class="required form-control">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix any of the following:\n  Document has multiple elements referenced with ARIA with the same id attribute: q']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.ieee.org/
        Error: duplicate-id-aria
        Description: Ensures every id attribute value used in ARIA and in labels is unique
        Suggested change: ARIA elements share the same id.
        Incorrect: <input type="search" name="q" id="q" title="Search all IEEE websites" placeholder="Search all IEEE websites" class="required form-control">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The error "duplicate-id-aria" suggests that there is at least one id attribute value used in ARIA that is not unique. The incorrect code provided has an input element with an `id` attribute value of "q". This id is also used in the label for the search input. To fix this, we should ensure that the id attributes are unique within the ARIA structure. Additionally, it's a good practice to add `aria-describedby` if there is any text that describes the purpose of the element, instead of using `title`. 

Correct: 
```html
<input type="search" name="q" id="search-bar" placeholder="Search all IEEE websites" class="required form-control">
<label for="search-bar" aria-describedby="search-description">Search all IEEE websites</label>
```

In this corrected version, I have changed the `id` attribute from "q" to "search-bar" to ensure uniqueness. I also removed the `title` attribute and added `aria-describedby="search-description"` to the `<label>` element to provide a description of the search input, which is more accessible for screen readers.

The issue mentioned is about "aria-allowed-role", which suggests that the `role` attribute on the `<iframe>` is being used with an ARIA role that's not allowed for the element. An `<iframe>` typically doesn't need an ARIA role as its built-in semantics can be sufficient. However, if an ARIA role is set, it should be one that's valid for an `<iframe>`, such as `region` or `presentation`. ```

This change removes the unnecessary ARIA attributes, adhering to the best practice of not using ARIA attributes when they are not required for the role of the element.

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The provided code snippet seems to lack the 'main' landmark role which is essential for screen readers and other assistive technologies to navigate the webpage effectively. The 'main' landmark role helps distinguish the main content of a webpage from other non-main content. It is crucial for accessibility.

Corrected code snippet:
```html
<html lang="en" class="js-focus-visible" data-js-focus-visible="">
<body>
    <!-- Main content should go here -->
    <main>
        <!-- Content of the main area -->
    </main>
</body>
</html>
```

Explanation: I added a 'main' element to the HTML structure. This new element is now the main container for the primary content of the webpage. It helps ensure that the page adheres to the requirement of having only one 'main' landmark role per page, which is beneficial for accessibility.

Thought: The `aria-hidden` attribute is being used to hide elements in a slider, which is not a recommended practice as it can cause accessibility issues. It's better to hide elements using CSS or to include them in the tab order but not make them focusable. 

Correct: We can change the `aria-hidden="true"` attribute to an empty string `aria-hidden=""` and make sure the elements are not focusable in CSS by setting `pointer-events: none;` and `user-select: none;`.

prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.taylorguitars.com/
        Error: landmark-unique
        Description: Landmarks should have a unique role or role/label/title (i.e. accessible name) combination
        Suggested change: Multiple landmarks of the same type should have unique and descriptive labels.
        Incorrect: <footer role="contentinfo" id="es-pagination" class="row">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The error message suggests that there are multiple landmarks of the same type (in this case, possibly footer) without unique labels or roles. The suggestion is to give these landmarks unique and descriptive labels. So, I will add unique 'aria-label' attributes to the footer tags and ensure that the roles are clearly defined.

Correct: 

```html
<footer role="contentinfo" aria-label="Footer: Contact Information and Site Map">
    <!-- Footer content here -->
</footer>
```

In this corrected version, I have added an 'aria-label' attribute to the footer tag. The text within the quotes defines a descriptive label for the footer, which helps clarify its purpose to screen readers and other assistive technologies. The role attribute stays as "contentinfo", which is suitable for a footer that provides information about the site's content.

description: Ensures ARIA attributes are allowed for an element's role
help: Elements must only use allowed ARIA attributes
html: [['<div id="onetrust-banner-sdk" class="otCenterRounded default vertical-align-content" aria-modal="true" tabindex="0">']]
failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  ARIA attribute is not allowed: aria-modal="true"']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.weebly.com/
        Error: aria-allowed-attr
        Description: Ensures ARIA attributes are allowed for an element's role
        Suggested change: Invalid ARIA attribute used.
        Incorrect: <div id="onetrust-banner-sdk" class="otCenterRounded default vertical-align-content" aria-modal="true" tabindex="0">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The error message indicates that there's an issue with the ARIA attributes used in the element with id="onetrust-banner-sdk". It mentions that some ARIA attributes are not allowed for certain roles. The incorrect code assigns `aria-modal="true"` and `tabindex="0"` to this element. The `aria-modal` attribute is used to indicate that an element is modal (i.e., blocks interaction with the rest of the page). However, it must be used with a role that supports modal behavior, such as `dialog` or `alertdialog`. Also, `tabindex="0"` makes the element focusable, which might not be the intended behavior for this element.

Corrected code: To fix this, I will change the `aria-modal="true"` to a more appropriate ARIA role and remove `tabindex="0"`. The `dialog` role would be suitable for a modal banner.

Correct: 
```html
<div id="onetrust-banner-sdk" class="otCenterRounded default vertical-align-content" role="dialog" aria-modal="true">
```

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The given error description suggests that the issue is related to a missing label for a select element, which is crucial for accessibility as it helps users understand what action or choice is expected from them. To address this, I will add a descriptive `label` tag that corresponds to the `select` element.

Corrected: 

```html
<select id="u_0_1v_8t" class="_9tg0 _afo4 _afoc" aria-labelledby="select-label">
    <!-- existing options -->
</select>
<label id="select-label" for="u_0_1v_8t">Choose your option</label>
```

Explanation:
- Added `aria-labelledby` attribute to the `select` element, which refers to the ID of the label element.
- Created a `label` element with the ID `select-label` and added the text `Choose your option` as the label text.
- The `for` attribute in the `label` tag corresponds to the `id` of the `select` element to associate the label with the select element.

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The buttons on this website seem to be styled using classes and do not have explicit names or text that can be read by screen readers. They are data-driven and rely on the data attributes like `data-ms-clickable` and `data-ms` for their functionality. However, for accessibility, it is important that buttons have clear text or roles for screen readers to interpret.

Correct: 
```html
<button class="_afwh _adig _afpc" type="button" role="button" aria-label="Search">Search</button>
```

Explanation:
1. **Type**: The type attribute was changed from "normal" to "button". This is more semantically meaningful for the role of the button.
2. **Role**: Added `role="button"` to clearly indicate this is a button element.
3. **Aria-label**: Provided `aria-label="Search"` to explicitly state what the button does, which is particularly important for screen readers and users with visual impairments.

failureSummary: [['Fix all of the following:\n  Document does not have a main landmark']]
prompts_baseline_two:
You are operating on this website: https://www.whatsapp.com/
        Error: landmark-one-main
        Description: Ensures the document has a main landmark
        Suggested change: There should only be one 'main' landmark role per page.
        Incorrect: <html lang="en" id="facebook" class="">
responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The initial HTML structure seems to have misleading attributes and roles, which is not ideal for accessibility. The 'id' attribute should not be 'facebook' as it doesn't represent the context of the page. Also, the 'landmark-one-main' error indicates the lack of a 'main' landmark role which is crucial for screen readers to understand the primary content of the page. 

Correct: 

```html
<html lang="en">
<head>
<title>WhatsApp</title>
</head>
<body>
<main id="main-content">
<!-- rest of the page content goes here -->
</main>
</body>
</html>
```

In the fixed version, I have removed the misleading 'id' and 'class' attributes from the HTML tag. I've also added an 'id' attribute to the 'main' element, which serves as the 'main' landmark role as suggested. This provides a clear indication of the primary content area of the page, which is essential for accessibility.

responses_baseline_two:
Thought: The buttons on this website are missing accessible names, which makes it difficult for users who rely on screen readers to understand the function of each button. They need descriptive text that accurately reflects their functionality, and in this case, they are navigation buttons.

Corrected: 

1. <button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Previous Tire Family"> 
2. <button class="RedBtn_btnWrapper__pOAqs TiresPresentation_redBtn__6y_mE" aria-label="Next Tire Family"> 

Thought: By adding the `aria-label` attribute with a descriptive text like "Previous Tire Family" and "Next Tire Family", we have provided enough information for screen readers to accurately describe the buttons' functions to the users.
